## Project Description

In this mini project, we will learn to use LlamaIndex to create a resume reader. You can download your resume by going on to the Linkedin profile page, clicking on More, and then Save to PDF.

Before running anything, we must install llama-index, openai, and pypdf. We are installing pypdf so that we can read and convert PDF files.

We will use the ElevenLabs' TTS API. You need to provide ElevenLabs API key to initiate the audio generation function. You can get an API key at ElevenLabs website for free.

::: {#9b2a7973 .cell execution_count=1}
``` {.python .cell-code}
%pip install llama-index openai pypdf
```

``` {.python .cell-code}
from timeit import default_timer as timer
import os
import nltk

# Get the API keys from environment variable for the demo
OPENAI_API_KEY = os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY")
ELEVENLABS_KEY = os.getenv("ELEVENLABS_KEY")

if not OPENAI_API_KEY:
    raise ValueError("OPENAI_API_KEY is not set in your environment variables!")

if not ELEVENLABS_KEY:
    raise ValueError("ELEVENLABS_KEY is not set in your environment variables!")

# Set it for OpenAI
os.environ["OPENAI_API_KEY"] = OPENAI_API_KEY

# set it for ElevenLabs
os.environ["ELEVENLABS_KEY"] = ELEVENLABS_KEY

# Download NLTK stopwords
start = timer()
nltk.download("stopwords")
end = timer()

print(f"Time elapsed: {end - start:.4f} seconds")
```

``` {.python .cell-code}
resume = SimpleDirectoryReader("private-data").load_data()
new_index = TreeIndex.from_documents(resume)
```
:::


## Running a query

Once the data has been indexed, you can begin asking questions by using `as_query_engine()`. This function enables you to ask questions about specific information within the document and receive a corresponding response with the help of OpenAI GPT-3 text-davinci-003 model.

::: {#3cce5188 .cell execution_count=5}
``` {.python .cell-code}
start = timer()

query_engine = new_index.as_query_engine()
response = query_engine.query("When did Chaance graduate?")

end = timer()

print(f'Time elapsed: {end - start:.4f} seconds') # time in seconds
print(response)
```

## Saving and loading the context

Creating an index is a time-consuming process. We can avoid re-creating indexes by saving the context. By default, the following command will save the index store in the ./storage directory.

::: {#74e48d34 .cell execution_count=11}
``` {.python .cell-code}
new_index.storage_context.persist()
```
:::


::: {#0e0527f6 .cell execution_count=12}
``` {.python .cell-code}
from llama_index.core import StorageContext, load_index_from_storage

storage_context = StorageContext.from_defaults(persist_dir="./storage")
index = load_index_from_storage(storage_context)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
INFO:llama_index.core.indices.loading:Loading all indices.
Loading all indices.
```

## Chat Interface

Instead of Q&A, we can also use LlamaIndex to create a personal Chatbot. We just have to initialize the index with the `as_chat_engine()` function.

We will ask a simple question.

::: {#1fa5cfc0 .cell execution_count=14}
``` {.python .cell-code}
query_engine = index.as_chat_engine()
response = query_engine.chat("What is the job title of Chaance in 2019?")
print(response)
```

# Building Wiki Text to Speech with LlamaIndex

First, we will scrape the data from Brazil - Wikipedia webpage and save it as brazil_text.txt file in the data folder.

::: {#b2c4926c .cell execution_count=20}
``` {.python .cell-code}
start = timer()

from pathlib import Path

import requests

response = requests.get(
    "https://en.wikipedia.org/w/api.php",
    params={
        "action": "query",
        "format": "json",
        "titles": "Brazil",
        "prop": "extracts",
        # 'exintro': True,
        "explaintext": True,
    },
).json()
page = next(iter(response["query"]["pages"].values()))
brazil_text = page["extract"]

data_path = Path("data")

if not data_path.exists():
    Path.mkdir(data_path)

with open("data/brazil_text.txt", "w") as fp:
    fp.write(brazil_text)

end = timer()
print(f'Time elapsed: {end - start:.4f} seconds') # time in seconds
print(response)
```
